bioghist.p: Ira Wolfert (1908-1997) was a writer and journalist. In 1930, he received a bachelor's degree from the Columbia University School of Journalism. He worked for the North American Newspaper Alliance in the 1930s and 1940s; he was a war correspondent during World War II, and in 1943 he received a Pulitzer Prize for a series of articles he wrote about a sea battle off Guadalcanal. He also wrote fiction, and was the author of the acclaimed 1943 novel Tucker's People. His wife, Helen X. Herschdorfer Wolfert (1901-1985) was a poet. She was a graduate of Hunter College, and taught in the New York City schools for ten years. Her works include two volumes of poems: Landlady and Tenant and Music, as well as articles, poems, and reviews published in magazines such as Poetry, Harper's Bazaar, the New Republic, and The Nation. The couple's son, Michael Wolfert (1936-2001), was a novelist.
